data.title: Things to do in the San Gabriel Valley area, Aug. 9-16
data.meta_description: There's always something different or new to do in the San Gabriel Valley area.
data.text:
Summer isn’t over yet. Spend a last hurrah at the Campfire Sunset outdoor concert series at Kidspace Museum. Masanga Marimba brings its Afro-Latin summer jam to the Stone Hollow Amphitheater at 5:30 and 7 p.m. Friday, Aug. 9, at 480 N. Arroyo Blvd., Pasadena. The ensemble includes Zimbabwean marimbas, drums, percussion, trumpet, trombone and vocals. Included with general admission and free for members. Dance and sing along, create cool crafts and made the best summer memories. The museum will be open until 8 p.m. Bring your own picnic or buy food from the café or food trucks.

For more information, visit kidspacemuseum.org or call 626-449-9144.

Summer Together: Reconnect, belong and support small businesses at “Summer Together,” presented by the social app YUZU and Golden Guide, a nonprofit that connects Asian American, Native Hawaiian, and Pacific Islander (AANHPI) communities. Start with a photo booth party from 6 to 9 p.m. Friday, Aug. 9, at Portrait Space, 100 W. Green St., Old Pasadena

Show off your board game prowess at a social from 2 to 7 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 10, at Blossom Market Hall, 264 S. Mission Drive, San Gabriel. For more information, visit Goldenguide.org/summer-together.

Pasadena Pops: Michael Cavanaugh sings Paul Simon, Billy Joel and more with Larry Blank conducting at the next Pasadena Pops concert on Saturday, Aug. 10, at the Los Angeles County Arboretum, 301 N. Baldwin Ave., Arcadia. Gates open at 5:30 p.m. for picnicking with the concert set for 7:30 p.m. Tickets start at $15. For more information, visit pasadenasymphony-pops.org or call 626-793-7172.

Then there were four: The Megan Shung Quartet performs at the Vroman’s Summer Music Series at 5 p.m. Saturday, Aug. 10, outdoors at Vroman’s Paseo, 695 E. Colorado Blvd., Pasadena. Admission is free. Inspired by folk, jazz and their own compositions this ensemble is led by Megan Shung on violin, and includes Marlon Martinez on bass, Zach Reaves on cello, Ryan Whyman on keyboard, and Forrest Robinson on percussion. For more information, call 626-449-5320 or visit vromans.com.

A new look at the American Dream: Alejandra Campoverdi has been a child on welfare, a White House aide in the Obama administration, a Harvard alum, and a gang member’s girlfriend. She discusses “First Gen,” her story of generational inheritance and belonging with Al Madrigal at 2 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 11, at Vroman’s Bookstore, 695 E. Colorado Blvd., Pasadena. Admission is free. For more information, call 626-449-5320 or visit vromans.com.

Nisei Week Japanese Festival – Los Angeles: The 82nd Nisei Week events include special cultural activities, entertainment and exhibits throughout Little Tokyo, Aug. 10-18. The Grand Parade, 4 p.m. Aug. 11. Festival map: https://niseiweek.org/festival/#map. 213-687-7183. Email: info@niseiweek.org. niseiweek.org

The “Natsumatsuri Family Festival” — at the Japanese American National Museum — includes cultural performances, activities and crafts, 11 a.m.-5 p.m. Aug. 10. Free. Location, 100 N. Central Ave., Los Angeles. Details: www.janm.org/events/2024-08-10/2024-natsumatsuri-family-festival

Also, the Japanese American Community and Cultural Center (244 S. San Pedro St., Los Angeles) has a schedule of activities, Aug. 10-18. The JACCC presents the “Plaza Festival” — Aug. 17-18 — that includes entertainment, food and shopping, 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Aug. 17; and on the second day, 11 a.m.-4 p.m. Aug. 18, a “Taiko Gathering,” with local Japanese drum groups. Details on the Aug. 10-18 schedule at the JACCC: jaccc.org/events/82nd-annual-nisei-week-jaccc/

Nisei Week Japanese Festival winds up with a closing ceremony and “Ondo Street Dance Party,” 3:45-7 p.m. Aug. 18 (First Street between Central Avenue and San Pedro Street). niseiweek.org

Nisei Week Japanese Festival Grand Parade: The parade includes traditional Japanese taiko drum performers, local community groups, high schools, elected officials and representatives, and the newly crowned 2024 Nisei Week queen and court, 4 p.m. Aug. 11. Grand marshal is David Ono, KABC-7 news anchor, and the parade marshal is actress Amy Hill. The route begins at Central Avenue; on Central and heading west on Second Street; turning north on San Pedro Street; turning east on First Street; turning south and ending on Central Avenue. 213-687-7183. Email: info@niseiweek.org. niseiweek.org/events/grand-parade/

Final note: In La Verne, The Answer classic rock band performs the final summer concert in the park at 6:30 p.m. Sunday, Aug. 11, at Heritage Park, 5001 Via de Mansion, La Verne. Admission is free. For more information, visit cityoflaverne.org.

All rock and roll: The Chicago tribute band, South Pasadena Transit Authority, closes out the series from 7 to 9 p.m. Tuesday, Aug. 13, at Memorial Park, 320 N. Orange Place. Admission is free. For more information, call 626-812-5280.

Summer concerts: Stretch those summer vibes at the Pasadena Senior Center’s free summer concerts for all ages Mondays from Aug. 14 to Sept. 4, at the center, 85 E. Holly St. Dad’s Band Plus One opens up the series from 5 to 7 p.m. Monday, Aug. 14; followed by JazzZone and its repertoire of classic jazz, funk, and R&B on Aug. 21. The Susie Hansen Latin band delivers its fiery brand of salsa on Monday, Aug. 28 and The Great American Swing Band delivers a Labor Day concert on Sept. 4. Reservations, residency in Pasadena or membership in the senior center are not required. For more information, visit pasadenaseniorcenter.org or call 626-795-4331.

Racing the speedway: Racers battle it out for the Junior Kurtz Memorial Cup title and trophy at 6 p.m. Wednesday, Aug. 14, at Industry Hills Expo Center, 16200 Temple Ave., City of Industry. The first race is at 7:30 p.m. Tickets are $20 for adults and $15 for youth 11-17, seniors 65 and older and military. Parking is $5. For more information, visit industryhillsspeedway.com.

Downtown happening: Baldwin Park’s Downtown Street Market happens at Maine Avenue between Ramona Boulevard and Clark Street Thursdays from 5 to 9 p.m. through Aug. 29. DJ Stilo Rolas spins tunes from 5 to 7 p.m. before Classic Journey tribute band and Tenampa Brass Band perform on two stages Thursday, Aug. 15. Admission is free. For more information, visit baldwinpark.com, call 626-813-5245, Ext. 311 or email arojo@baldwinpark.com.

Save the date: Whittier Community Theatre presents: “9 to 5: The Musical” playing Sept. 6 to 21, at 7630 Washington Ave, Whittier. Dolly Parton’s classic comedy tells the story of three female office workers living out their fantasies of getting even with and overthrowing their terrible boss. Tickets are $20-$25. For more information, visit whittiercommunitytheatre.org or call (562)-696-0600.

Ongoing events

A case for refugees: A suitcase with a bloody handle. A discarded baby sandal. Humaira Abid’s haunting exhibition “Searching for Home” features sculpted wooden creations invoking the global refugee crisis and the lives it upends. The exhibition closes on Aug. 18 at USC Pacific Asia Museum, 46 N. Los Robles Ave., Pasadena. Admission is $15 for adults, $15 for students with ID and $12 for seniors 65 and older. Admission is free the second Sunday of the month. For more information, visit pacificasiamuseum.usc.edu or call 626-787-2680.

Turn the page: Stock up on your TBR pile. The Friends of the Pasadena Public Library Bookstore invites all readers to choose from used books, DVDs, CDs, LPs and lots of children’s books. Store hours are 11 a.m. to 4 p.m. Monday through Thursday and Saturday, closed Friday and Sunday. The bookstore is at the Jefferson Elementary School campus, 1500 E. Villa Ave., between Hill and Allen avenues, in Pasadena. Donations are welcome. For more information, email Adrienne at phrogg8@gmail.com.

To market: The Altadena Neighborhood Farmers Market is open from 4 to 8 p.m. Fridays, at Loma Alta Park, 3330 N. Lincoln Ave., Altadena. Admission is free. The nonprofit Raw Inspiration offers the market as a way for children to learn the value of organic gardening and healthy eating. For more information, email info@rawinspiration.org or visit rawinspiration.org.

Farm fresh everything: The Farmer’s Market @ Mt. SAC is open from 8 a.m. to 1 p.m. Saturdays, at Parking Lot B, 1100 N. Grand Ave., Walnut. Sample pastries from Le Honore’ French Bakery, in-season fruits and vegetables, an Asian vegetables stand, arts and crafts along with ready-to-eat dishes such as dumplings. Lots of vendors offer handmade items and plants too. For more information, call 909-869-0701, email info@regionalchambersgv.com, visit regionalchambersgv.com or find “MtSacFarmersMarket” on Facebook.

Market news: Duarte Farmer’s Market is open from 4 to 7:30 p.m. Wednesdays, at the southeast corner of the Santa Teresita Assisted Living parking lot, 819 Buena Vista St., Duarte. Say hello to the Carmelite Sisters, shop for dinner, pick up sweet treats and discover new vendors. For more information, visit duartechamber.com/duarte-farmers-market.

It’s all lapidary: The Pasadena Lapidary Society meets from 7 to 8:45 p.m. on the third Tuesday of the month, except December, in the Fellowship Hall of Santa Anita Church, 226 W. Colorado Blvd., Arcadia. All were welcome. For more information, visit pasadenalapidary.org, or check out their social media on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter.

Wednesday night market: Whittier Uptown Association presents Wednesday Night Markets from 4:30 to 8:30 p.m. Wednesdays, on historic Greenleaf Avenue, from Wardman to Bailey streets. Stroll past local vendors, food and art. For more information, visit whittieruptown.org or call (562) 696-2662.

Play ball: Pasadena Senior Center sponsors Crown Valley senior co-ed softball teams. Players meet for practice and scrimmage games from 8 to 10 a.m. Mondays at Farnsworth Park in Altadena and Thursdays at Arcadia County Park. Players over 50 are welcome. For more information, call Marge Mayotte-Hirn at (626) 377-5631; email ssbslugger@yahoo.com or visit intercitysoftball.org.

Local history: Monrovia Historical Museum is open from 1 to 4 p.m. Thursdays and Sundays, at 742 E. Lemon Ave. Come and discover Monrovia’s amazing history. Admission is free. Docent-led tours are available. For more information, call (626) 357-9537 or visit monroviahistoricalmuseum.org.

New horizons: The Arcadia Travelers Club, designed for seniors 50 and older interested in travel and fellowship, is a nonprofit that offers day outings and extended day trips. It is open to anyone for a $10 annual fee. The group meets monthly at the Arcadia Community Center, 365 Campus Drive, Arcadia. For more information, visit arcadiatravelers.org or call (626) 821-4377.

It’s in the cards: West Covina Cribbage Club welcomes new members to its weekly meetings at 6 p.m. Mondays, at Denny’s, 1150 S. Seventh Ave., Hacienda Heights. For more information, call Elaine at (626) 330-3170.

Send calendar items to Anissa V. Rivera at sgvncalendar@gmail.com. Please send items at least three weeks before the event. Please list phone, email and/or website for additional information.
